creator: vadimk@quadrus.com
text:
I would like to have a task where you can create a file set that would find one
file and have the task set a property with the full path to that file. For example

<resolve property="filename">
     <fileset dir="${MyDir}">
           <include name="**/myfile.xml" />
     </fileset>
</resolve>

after this task is run the property filename would have the full path to the
file. The task would have to check if the fileset captures more than one file,
potentially we could have an option to either fail or to capture the first match.

creator: jan@materne.de
text:
We could do that ... especially if its nearly written :-)

In the meanwhile you can use the one provided in the manual "Tasks using 
Properties, Filesets & Paths" [1] with sources on [2].

Would that be what you want?

BTW according to the "WhichResource" that task would be renamed to "Which".
Discussion started at [3] and name suggested at [4].

[1] http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/*checkout*/ant/docs/manual/tutorial-tasks-
filesets-properties.html?content-type=text%2Fplain
[2] http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/*checkout*/ant/docs/manual/tutorial-tasks-
filesets-properties.zip
[3] http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=ant-dev&m=106448780322452&w=2
[4] http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=ant-dev&m=106450849616718&w=2

Don't forget that <pathconvert> can do what is requested with the exception of 
the "one file only" rule.  Just thinking off the top of my head, File.list() 
being what it is, if I needed this I would try to write a custom Fileset that 
you might use like this:

<filesubset id="myid" sort="alpha|date|size|random" descending="false|true" 
count="n">
  <fileset refid="myfs" />
</filesubset>

Yet another possibly fun thing to do...

text:
Couldn't you use <pathconvert/> to do the same thing? As long as the fileset 
you pass resolves onlu to one file, the result should be exactly what you want.

The pathconvert would work, but if a build runs on multiple platforms the call
to pathconvert would get pretty messy. I suppose a resolve task isn't a super
necessary feature. I could write it, but if there's enough concensus we can
probably close this bug.
